DestinyHistoricalStatsDestinyHistoricalStatsActivity

properties.name: directorActivityHash
properties.description: The unique hash identifier of the DestinyActivityDefinition that was played.
properties.rawdescription: The unique hash identifier of the DestinyActivityDefinition that was played.

properties.name: instanceId
properties.description: The unique identifier for this specific match that was played. This value can be used to get additional data about this activity such as who else was playing via the GetPostGameCarnageReport endpoint.
properties.rawdescription: The unique identifier for this *specific* match that was played.  This value can be used to get additional data about this activity such as who else was playing via the GetPostGameCarnageReport endpoint.

properties.name: isPrivate
properties.description: Whether or not the match was a private match.
properties.rawdescription: Whether or not the match was a private match.

properties.name: membershipType
properties.description: The Membership Type indicating the platform on which this match was played.
properties.rawdescription: The Membership Type indicating the platform on which this match was played.

properties.name: mode
properties.description: Indicates the most specific game mode of the activity that we could find.
properties.rawdescription: Indicates the most specific game mode of the activity that we could find.

properties.name: modes
properties.description: The list of all Activity Modes to which this activity applies, including aggregates. This will let you see, for example, whether the activity was both Clash and part of the Trials of the Nine event.
properties.rawdescription: The list of all Activity Modes to which this activity applies, including aggregates. This will let you see, for example, whether the activity was both Clash and part of the Trials of the Nine event.

properties.name: referenceId
properties.description: The unique hash identifier of the DestinyActivityDefinition that was played. If I had this to do over, it'd be named activityHash. Too late now.
properties.rawdescription: The unique hash identifier of the DestinyActivityDefinition that was played. If I had this to do over, it\'d be named activityHash. Too late now.

interfaces.name: DestinyHistoricalStatsDestinyHistoricalStatsActivity
DestinyHistoricalStatsDestinyHistoricalStatsPeriodGroup

properties.name: activityDetails
properties.description: If the period group is for a specific activity, this property will be set.
properties.rawdescription: If the period group is for a specific activity, this property will be set.

properties.name: period
properties.description: Period for the group. If the stat periodType is day, then this will have a specific day. If the type is monthly, then this value will be the first day of the applicable month. This value is not set when the periodType is 'all time'.
properties.rawdescription: Period for the group. If the stat periodType is day, then this will have a specific day. If the type is monthly, then this value will be the first day of the applicable month. This value is not set when the periodType is \'all time\'.

properties.name: values
properties.rawdescription: Collection of stats for the period.

interfaces.name: DestinyHistoricalStatsDestinyHistoricalStatsValue

properties.name: activityId
properties.description: When a stat represents the best, most, longest, fastest or some other personal best, the actual activity ID where that personal best was established is available on this property.
properties.rawdescription: When a stat represents the best, most, longest, fastest or some other personal best, the actual activity ID where that personal best was established is available on this property.

properties.name: pga
properties.description: Per game average for the statistic, if applicable
properties.rawdescription: Per game average for the statistic, if applicable

properties.name: weighted
properties.description: Weighted value of the stat if a weight greater than 1 has been assigned.
properties.rawdescription: Weighted value of the stat if a weight greater than 1 has been assigned.

interfaces.name: DestinyHistoricalStatsDestinyHistoricalStatsValue
DestinyHistoricalStatsDestinyHistoricalStatsValuePair

properties.name: displayValue
properties.rawdescription: Localized formated version of the value.

components.name: ClanSearchViewComponent
components.templateData:
Destiny Clan Dashboard

View your clan's activity with ease.

This app is a passion project and I should probably put a bunch of marketing nonsense here.

I hope you find this thing useful. Send me your feedback

Find Your Clan help

Find your clan and any additional clans you wish to track. Don't have clan?
Try and have a look around.

warning

Adding too many clans will impact the performance of the application

date_range

Seasonal Progress

View seasonal progress on both a clan and player level.

group

Roster Activity

Find out who has been the most active over the last year by viewing interactive heatmaps.

reduce_capacity

Activity Stats

Track who has cleared what, who has gotten the rare drops and completed the hardest challenges.

verified_user

Seal Completion

Celebrate the accomplishment of completing seals with your clan. Easily view who's finished seals and find out who needs help.

{{year}} - @WorthyD - Source Code - Not Affiliated with Bungie

components.sourceCode:
import { Component, Input, Output, EventEmitter } from '@angular/core'; import { User } from './User'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-header', template: `

Acme

Welcome, {{ user.name }}!
`, styleUrls: ['./header.css'], }) export default class HeaderComponent { @Input() user: User | null = null; @Output() onLogin = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onLogout = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onCreateAccount = new EventEmitter(); }

components.name: PageComponent
components.template:
Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
components.sourceCode:
import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { User } from './User'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-page', template: `

Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
`, styleUrls: ['./page.css'], }) export default class PageComponent { user: User | null = null; doLogout() { this.user = null; } doLogin() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } doCreateAccount() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } }

components.name: RenderedViewComponent
components.templateData:
{{text}}
<ng-template libDynamicComp></ng-template>
<ng-container *ngFor="let view of childrenViews">
  <lib-rendered-view *ngIf="view" [class]="view.classList || ''" [ngStyle]="view.styles || {}" [text]="view['text']"
    [component]="view['component']" [data]="view['data']" [childrenViews]="view['children']">
  </lib-rendered-view>
</ng-container>

` })
